title: Stochastic Processes and Active Inference
description: Mathematical treatment of stochastic processes and their role in modeling temporal dynamics in Active Inference.
learning_objectives: Understand stochastic processes in Active Inference
Model temporal dependencies in generative models

content.overview: Stochastic processes provide the mathematical foundation for modeling temporal dynamics in Active Inference. They describe how system states evolve over time and enable prediction, filtering, and control in dynamic environments.

markov_processes.definition: Future state depends only on current state: p(s_{t+1} | s_t, s_{t-1}, ...) = p(s_{t+1} | s_t)
markov_processes.ergodicity: Long-term behavior independent of initial conditions

continuous_time_processes.wiener_process: Brownian motion as continuous limit of random walk
continuous_time_processes.diffusion_processes: General class of continuous Markov processes

filtering_and_smoothing.kalman_filter: Optimal filtering for linear Gaussian systems
filtering_and_smoothing.particle_filter: Monte Carlo approximation for general systems

examples.name: Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Process
examples.interpretation: Pulls toward mean μ with strength θ
examples.application: Neural activity, stock prices, temperature regulation

information_theoretic_analysis.entropy_rate: Entropy production rate in stationary processes
information_theoretic_analysis.predictive_information: How much future can be predicted from past

interactive_exercises.description: Simulate different types of stochastic processes
Implement filtering algorithms for temporal models

common_misconceptions.clarification: Markov assumption simplifies but may not always hold
Nonlinear filtering methods exist for general systems
Have statistical regularities that can be exploited
